text: when summer stone fruits like peaches
and nectarines are in the peak of season
I always go back and forth between pie
or crumble bar well today we're gonna
have the best of both worlds it's a
peach pie crumble bar that uses a press
in shortbread crust first you have to
prep your pan I have an 8 inch square
baking pan that I've buttered and lined
with parchment and then butter the
parchment again and I love to use these
handy little binder clips to keep the
parchment from collapsing down into
whatever it is you're baking and do
leave about a 2 inch overhang on your
pan so that you can very easily lift out
the bars once they've cooled for the
shortbread crust we have a stick and
five tablespoons of unsalted butter
that's going to get a cup of sugar and
these just need to combine until the
mixture is nice and light and fluffy and
you'll want to have a handy little
spatula like this and just scrape the
mixture down into the bottom of the bowl
again a few times okay you'll also
notice that the butter mixture becomes a
little paler as it beats only two more
ingredients to go before we have our
shortbread crust but before we add those
the bowl needs one more quick scrape
down okay and when you're adding these
dry ingredients you want to do that on a
slower speed otherwise the whole thing
will just come up into your face I've
done it many times that I don't
recommend it salt first so that it
evenly incorporates into the butter
mixture the teaspoon of coarse salt and
two cups of all-purpose flour I'm just
going to reduce the speed a little bit
as I start to add the flour just a
little bit at a time this will also
ensure that it doesn't fly out of the
mixing bowl do you add it and this just
needs to beat until it becomes crumbly
and clumpy it's already happening yeah
that looks pretty darn good okay
so two and a half cups of this mixture
is going to get pressed into the bottom
of the pan and two and a half that's
about a half close enough and just set
the rest aside that will be used for the
crumble
popping OH and actually I'm taking this
measure back because it makes quick work
of pressing the mixture evenly into the
bottom also because we're adding fruit
to this we need to create walls on the
sides so just press some of that mixture
about halfway up the sides of the pan
this is eight inch baking dishes two
inches deep so that would be about a
one-inch wall okay I think we're nearly
there the walls just prevent the juices
from flowing up and under the crust
which is not such a good idea because
then you might have a soggy bottom
nobody likes a soggy bottom okay and you
can just set this aside while you work
on the filling now for the filling we
need one and a quarter pounds of peaches
or nectarines if you prefer those I have
cling peaches today which means that the
stone in the center clings to the flesh
it doesn't just sort of come right out
like a freestone peach but what you can
do is turn it gently so the one side
pops out quite easily and this side is
the Beast I like to take a little
demitasse spoon and just run the spoon
around the pit you don't want to lose
any of that flesh oh all right and into
small pieces you could certainly do this
with plums as well that would be
delicious or apricots whatever your
preferred stone fruit is half a cup of
granulated sugar into the bowl and salt
always half a teaspoon lemon juice any
kind of pie like this or bar in this
case takes acidity it needs it to
balance the sweetness and it also brings
out the natural flavors of the fruit you
don't actually taste the lemon per se
about a tablespoon and you do need a
little bit of a thickener I like to use
flour two tablespoons and just give this
a quick toss to combine
what I like to do is I just fold it
together until I don't see any more dry
flour and that tells me that it's all
been mixed evenly
alright I would say that looks ready to
go and into the bottom crust may seem
like a lot of fruit but it really does
cook down and it looks like I've made my
walls of shortbread just high enough you
should also have your oven preheated to
375 degrees at this point and now for
the crumble topping I like nice big
chunks of topping leaving some space in
between so that you see that fruit sort
of popping through and as you do it just
give that mixture a squeeze in your hand
before you crumble it into larger chunks
and that'll help ensure that it holds
together as it bakes already smells so
good and it's not even in the oven yet
and into the oven this can now go our
peach pie crumble bar is cooled and
ready to cut and eat very important let
it cool in the pan for about 20 minutes
and then lift from the parchment and let
it cool completely on a wire rack before
you cut into it it cuts very easily into
bars and I like mine ala mode with
vanilla ice cream how pretty that is
YUM right on top nice generous scoop oh
yeah
and that makes for a delicious and
beautiful summertime dessert happy
eating
